Package naipmoro.gramm

Gramm is an Antlr-based Metamath proof verifier.

See: Description

  • Interface Summary 
    Interface Description
    Statement
    An interface to cover all Metamath statements: assertions (axioms and theorems) and hypotheses (variable-type and logical).
  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    Assertion
    A Metamath assertion, either an axiom or a theorem.
    CharStack
    A stack of characters used in compressed-proof verification.
    DisjPair
    A Metamath disjoint variable pair.
    Hypothesis
    A Metamath hypothesis, either variable-type or logical.
    Mandatory
    The mandatory elements of a Metamath assertion: its mandatory hypotheses and its mandatory disjoint variable pairs.
    MMFile
    A class to keep track of the Metamath source file and any subsequent included files.
    MMIncludeParseTreeListener
    A listener that walks the parse trees of included files.
    MMParseTreeListener
    A listener that walks the parse tree of a Metamath file and produces effects at specified nodes.
    MMParseTreeListener.MMBailLexer
    A lexer that bails out at the first lexical error.
    MMStack<T>
    A generic array-based stack, intended to be extended by concrete stacks.
    Proof
    A Metamath proof.
    ProofStack
    A stack of StatementCore objects used in proof verification.
    Scope
    A Metamath scope.
    ScopeStack
    The global scope stack and scope manager.
    StatementCore
    The essential elements of a statement (its type and its body) used by the proof verifer.
    SubstitutionMap
    A substitution map used in Metamath proof verification.
    Verifier
    The main class that initiates the verification of a Metamath source file.
  • Exception Summary 
    Exception Description
    MMException
    An exception that terminates the application.
    MMProofException
    An exception thrown in response to a proof error, it does not terminate the application.

Package naipmoro.gramm Description

Gramm is an Antlr-based Metamath proof verifier. From a BNF-like grammar of the Metamath language, Antlr4 creates a parser which, when fed a source file, generates a parse tree. Here's a small branch of set.mm's tree:

We walk the tree by extending an Antlr4-provided empty base listener. At particular terminal nodes of the tree, tokens are gathered and sent to the global ScopeStack for processing. The most important processing occurs via the proof nodes and involves calls to Proof.verify().
